Hermits, Heroes, and Demagogues: Dostoevsky's Repudiation of the Rational Actor Model

Richard Avramenko

This essay will explore Fyodor M. Dostoevsky's confrontation with enlightenment rationalism as manifest in the modern scientific approach to politics and political science. Whereas modern political science aims to regress all humans to the mean, Dostoevsky asks us not to forgot those folks who might be called outliers. Outliers are often the forgotten folk who make little difference in the story the statistical models try to tell. For Dostoevsky, these outliers are often hiding in the little spaces below the floorâ€”and this is the lesson of the Underground Man in his Notes from the Underground. This essay will therefore analyze the place of outliers--be they hermits, heroes, or demagogues--in Dostoevsky's distinctly Russian view of "Western" rationalism. Western rationalism, I will argue, is for Dostoevsky, the Baal that terrified him as he stood before the Crystal Palace at London's Universal Exhibition of 1862.
